data.title: Chomsky and Wittgenstein on Linguistic Competence
meta_keywords: 20th century philosophy; Wittgenstein Ludwig; Chomsky Noam; competence; language faculty; logical compulsion; rule-following; meaning
data.meta_description: Chomsky and Wittgenstein on Linguistic Competence
data.text:
Thomas McNally

Trinity College Dublin

Ireland

Thomas McNally’s research is focussed primarily on Wittgenstein’s later philosophy and its connection with contemporary debates in the philosophy of language. He completed his PhD at Trinity College Dublin on the topic of Wittgenstein, Kripke, and scepticism about meaning.

Sinéad McNally

Trinity College Dublin

Ireland

Sinéad McNally is a research psychologist specialising in psycholinguistics and child psychology. Her doctoral research investigated behavioural and developmental theories of language development. She is currently a Research Associate at the School of Psychology, Trinity College Dublin.

Boghossian, P., 2005. “Is meaning normative?” In A. Beckermann and C. Nimtz. Eds. Philosophy – Science – Scientific Philosophy. Paderborn: Mentis.

Brandom, R., 1994. Making It Explicit. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press.

Chomsky, N., 1986. Knowledge of Language. New York, Westport, Connecticut, London: Praeger.

Chomsky, N., 2005. “Language and the Brain.” In A. J. Saleemi, O-S. Bohn, & A. Gjedde, Eds. In Search of a Language for the Mind-Brain. Aarhus: Aarhus University Press.

Kripke, S., 1982. Wittgenstein on Rules and Private Language. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press.

McDowell, J., 2009. The Engaged Intellect: Philosophical Essays. Cambridge, MA & London: Harvard University Press.

McNally, T., Forthcoming. Wittgenstein’s Master Arguments.

Wikforss, Å., 2001. “Semantic Normativity.” Philosophical Studies, Vol. 102: 203-226.

Williams, M., 2007. “Blind Obedience: Rules, Community, and the Individual.” In: M. Williams, ed. 2007. Wittgenstein’s Philosophical Investigations: Critical Essays. Plymouth: Rowman and Littlefield.

Wittgenstein, L., 1956. Remarks on the Foundations of Mathematics. G. H. von Wright, R. Rhees, & G. E. M. Anscombe (eds.). G. E. M. Anscombe (trans.). Oxford: Blackwell.

Wittgenstein, L., 1958. The Blue and Brown Books. Oxford: Blackwell.

Wittgenstein, L., 2001. Philosophical Investigations. 3rd ed. G. E. M. Anscombe, trans. Oxford: Blackwell.

Wright, C., 2007. “Rule-following without Reasons: Wittgenstein’s Quietism and the Constitutive Question.” Ratio, Vol. 20: 481-502.
